<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>TITLE<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Tractable
Probabilistic Models for Big Relational Data<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>ABSTRACT<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>The
extraction of knowledge from the <span class=GramE>world wide web</span> and
other sources is a central problem in the data sciences with numerous
applications and wide-ranging implications for future technologies. There are
several existing information extraction projects such as the Google Knowledge
Graph, <span class=SpellE>DBpedia</span>, and NELL. These projects populate
large knowledge bases and are a valuable data set for bootstrapping statistical
relational models of the world's knowledge. These models enable innovative
technologies such as search engines that enrich keyword-based results with
entities, their attributes, and relations. Since inference and learning in
probabilistic models is NP-hard in general, there is a need to develop new
theories and algorithms that scale statistical relational models to large data
sets. To this end, I will present two lines of recent work. First, I will
describe symmetry-aware inference and learning, a framework that exploits both
symmetries and conditional independence to design classes of expressive yet
tractable probabilistic models. The framework provides a deep theoretical link
between symmetries and tractable inference in probabilistic models. Second, I
will present tractable probabilistic knowledge bases (TPKBs) featuring <span
class=SpellE>sublinear</span>, disk-based, and parallel inference algorithms.
TPKBs are designed so as to always compile to a poly-sized circuit
representation. We present a TPKB we have learned from existing information
extraction projects and apply it to data extraction and integration problems
such as entity resolution and linking.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>BIO<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Mathias
<span class=SpellE>Niepert</span> is a postdoctoral research associate at the
University of Washington in Seattle. He obtained a PhD from Indiana University.
His work has won best paper awards at international conferences such as UAI,
AAAI, IJCNLP, and ESWC. He is the principal investigator of a Google faculty
research award and a bilateral DFG-NEH research award. Mathias has also
co-organized several successful workshops and he is co-founder of several
open-source digital humanities projects such as the Indiana Philosophy Ontology
Project and the Linked Humanities Project.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l2 level1 lfo2'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Wingdings;mso-fareast-font-family:Wingdings;mso-bidi-font-family:
Wingdings'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>v<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>

class=SpellE>AI_Average</span>). It is sufficient to beat or tie it in any one

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:.5in;

class=SpellE>AI_Good</span> in the Final Tournament. It is sufficient to beat
or tie it in any one of your games.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:.5in;

style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>4 Feb 2015: A kind and helpful student

has difficulty correctly reading the previous CS-171 tests. For example, in
problems #3a and #3b on Quiz #2 from SQ’2004, the erroneous
“Y” on the key was corrected by an overlay in the PDF file of a red
X through the Y, and next to it a red N. However, this overlay is invisible on
a Mac (iPad), leading to incorrect understanding of the right answer.
Sometimes, the Mac PDF software appears to be incompatible with the Windows PDF
software. If you are using a Mac to read the previous CS-171 test PDF files and
something looks wrong, please look at it again from Windows. If it still looks
wrong, please bring it to my attention.<span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'><o:p></o:p></span></span></p>

<h2><a name="_Goal:"></a><span style='font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:red'>Goal:</span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
color:black'>The goal of this class is to familiarize you with the basic
principles of artificial intelligence. You will l</span><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>earn <span style='color:black'>some
</span>basic AI techniques, the problems for which they are applicable, and
their limitations.<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>The
course content is organized roughly around what are often considered to be three
central pillars of AI: Search, Logic, and Learning. Topics covered include
basic search, heuristic search, game playing, constraint satisfaction,
knowledge representation, logic and inference, probabilistic modeling, and
machine learning algorithms.<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>This is a broad
introductory survey course. We will move rapidly through the basic fundamentals
of a large number of AI topics. For every topic that we touch, there are
specialized techniques available to the sophisticated practitioner that will go
beyond what we are able to cover in 10 short weeks. The bright, interested, and
motivated student is encouraged to pursue advanced studies. In any case, if you
work hard, study hard, and master the presented material, you will emerge from
this course with a basic grasp of some of the fundamental methods that we use
to engineer intelligent systems.</span></b><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'> </span></b><span style='mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<div class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=center>

</div>

<h2><a name="_Class_Setup:"></a><span style='font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:red'>Class Setup:</span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>The
course will be primarily lecture-based.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> 
</span>There will be a Mid-term and a Final Exam.<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>On most second Tuesdays, the first 20
minutes will be an in-class pop quiz, followed by lecture (see specific dates
in <a href="#_Syllabus:">Syllabus below</a>).<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>The frequent quizzes are intended to
encourage you to stay current with the course material.<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span><u>All exams and quizzes may cover all
material presented in class, including lectures and assigned textbook reading.</u><span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Quizzes will cover mostly material
presented since the last quiz, and also may include questions that many
students missed on the previous quiz.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> 
</span>The Final Exam will cover mostly material since the Mid-term Exam, and
also will include many questions intended to encourage you to remember the
earlier material (i.e., it will be comprehensive). <u>Please study the previous
CS-171 quizzes and exams (<a href="#_Study_Guides_---">below</a>), which are
made available as study guides to help you learn and master the class material;
they are important guides about the performance that will be expected from you
now.</u><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>There
will be an AI coding project (see <a href="#_Project:_1">Project section below</a>).<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>You are allowed to do the project by
yourself, or you may form project teams of two students following the “<a
href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pair_programming">Pair Programming</a>”
paradigm.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Please note that you are
encouraged to discuss concepts, methods, algorithms, etc.; but you are forbidden
to copy: (1) source code from any source, or (2) text from any source unless
properly cited and set off as a quote.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> 
</span>Except for class materials provided from this class website, you must
invent and write all of your own code by yourself with your partner.<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Except for properly referenced material,
you must write all of your own project report by yourself with your partner.
Please note that your source code and project report are subject to analysis by
automated plagiarism detection programs, and that direct copying will be
treated as an act of academic dishonesty (please see the section on “<a
href="#_Academic_Honesty:">Academic Honesty</a>” below). Please start
your AI coding project earlier than you believe necessary; it will take longer
and be more difficult than you expect (<u>as is true of all coding projects
everywhere at all times</u>).<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>All
my AI project shells were written by former CS-171 students who became
interested in AI and signed up for CS-199 in order to pursue their interest and
write more interesting AI project shells.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> 
</span>Please let me know if this is of interest to you (CS-171 grade of A- or
better required).<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Homework
will be assigned, but is not graded. The reason is that prior student course
evaluations alerted me to the existence of student cheating by way of copying
the homework answers.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>I deplore
this degree of personal degradation in dishonest students, but I cannot control
it, and so I avoid the opportunity.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> 
</span>I remain determined to create a fair and honest educational experience
for all students, as best I can.<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";color:black'>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=left>

</span></h2>

"Times New Roman";color:black'><span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>

edition.<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<p><span style='mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:black'>The
course is based on, and the UCI bookstore has, the 3<sup>rd</sup> edition. The
assigned textbook reading is required, and is fair game for quizzes and
exams.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span></span><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:red'>You
place yourself at a distinct disadvantage if you do not have the textbook.</span></b><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>I expect that you have a personal copy
of the textbook, and quizzes and exams are written accordingly.</span></b><span
style='mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p><span style='mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:black'>Please
purchase or rent your own personal textbook for the quarter (and then resell it
back to the UCI Bookstore at the end if you don't want it for reference).</span>
<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='color:red'>Please do not jeopardize
your precious educational experience with the false economy of trying to save a
few dollars by not having a personal copy of the textbook.</span></b><span
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p><span style='mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:black'>Also,
for your convenience, I have requested that a copy of the textbook be placed on
reserve in the UCI Science Library.</span><strong><span style='font-weight:
normal;mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'> There is a two-hour check-out limit. </span></strong>However,
please understand that with high student enrollments, it is unrealistic to
expect that these thin reserves will always be available when you need
them.  <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='color:red'>Please
purchase or rent your own personal textbook.</span></b><strong><span
style='color:red;font-weight:normal;mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'><o:p></o:p></span></strong></p>

normal;mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>I do deplore the high cost of textbooks.<span

</span></span></span><![endif]><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:

adversarial search (game search) controller for a game-playing agent. <o:p></o:p></span></h2>

margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman"'>I expect to be able to run a tournament within which your AI
controllers will compete against each other for Bonus Points. Everyone’s

simply free, based on how many games your AI wins against other AIs. The top
10% winners will get 10% added to their project grade as a bonus; the second
10% will get 9%; the third 10% will get 8%; and so on.<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:.5in;

style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>EEE will

don’t count) in any of the course materials before I spot it too, and (2)
for helpful contributions to the class as we go along.<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>One bonus point is equivalent to one
quiz point.<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><a name="_Study_Habits:"></a><span style='font-size:12.0pt;font-family:
"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:red'>Study
Habits:</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>This
course is technical, rigorous, and demanding. You will be expected to learn and
master a large body of technical material in a very short period of <span
class=GramE>time,</span> and to demonstrate your mastery by (1) accurate
performance on frequent quizzes and exams, and (2) successful implementation of
an AI coding project.<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Although
I deliberately treat you as adults who are responsible for your own educational
decisions, and so lecture and discussion sections are optional ---
nevertheless, students who do not attend lecture or discussion sections are at
a serious disadvantage and do not succeed as well in this class.<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>They send me emails asking questions
that already were covered thoroughly and in detail during lecture and again in
discussion section.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>They miss
points on quizzes and exams that already have been discussed thoroughly. <u>Your
educational moments are precious, and your education now will be the single
most important factor in your future career success or failure.<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Please, make the most of your precious
educational moments now; please, attend both lecture and discussion section.</u><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Please
do not ever fall behind in the class material; instead, <u>study frequently and
diligently</u>. Please begin your AI coding project earlier than you believe
necessary; it will take longer and be more difficult than you expect (<u>as is
true of all coding projects everywhere at all times</u>).<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Please
work harder and study longer.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> 
</span>Please understand thoroughly all class material, and ask questions when
you do not understand.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Please
attend all lectures and discussion sections.<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Please come to lectures and discussion
sections prepared with questions about any material that is not clear.<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>Please do all assigned reading, both
before and again after lecture. Please review the lecture notes, several times
over, both before and again after lecture, until you understand every detail.
Please regularly attend office hours with me and the TA. Please ask questions
about any class material that is not absolutely crystal clear.<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Please
<u>work and understand all past quizzes and exams; they are important guides
about the performance that will be expected from you now.</u> Please work and
understand all the optional homework.<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Please
<u>OVERSTUDY!!</u><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><a name="_Syllabus:"></a><span style='font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:red'>Syllabus:</span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<p><b>The following represents a preliminary syllabus. Some changes in the
lecture sequence may occur due to earthquakes, fires, floods, wars, natural disasters,
unnatural disasters, or the discretion of the instructor based on class
progress.<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p><b>Background Reading and Lecture Slides will be changed or revised as the
class progresses at the discretion of the instructor.<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p><b>Please note:<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span><u>I sometimes
tweak or revise the lecture slides before or after the lecture, based upon
perceived improved student comprehension; please, always ensure that you have
the most current, up-to-date version.<o:p></o:p></u></b></p>

<p><b>Please <u>read</u> the assigned textbook reading and <u>review</u> the
lecture notes <u><span style='color:red'>in advance</span></u><span
style='color:red'> </span>of each lecture, then <u><span style='color:red'>again
after</span></u><span style='color:red'> </span>each lecture.<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
3'>                                    </span>The
program learns to build a car using a genetic algorithm.<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:
3'>                                    </span>If
you let this program run for a long time (>> 30 generations), you will
see that eventually it produces cars well suited to the terrain. This outcome
illustrates a general theme of genetic algorithms: very, very slow; but,
eventually, good performance. After all, it took ~3.6 billion years to evolve
humans from bacteria (<a
href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_evolutionary_history_of_life">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_evolutionary_history_of_life</a>).
Please note that this eventual good performance of genetic algorithms is
conditional upon a representation that allows good solutions to sub-problems to
be combined simply, by cross-over, into a globally good solution; if the vector
position of the features is completely randomized within the chromosome, any
such good performance is lost.<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<h2 style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-size:12.0pt'><span
style='mso-tab-count:2'>                        </span></span><span
class=GramE><span style='font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>“<a
href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_singularity">Technological
singularity</a>” --- Wikipedia.</span></span><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2 style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:1.5in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-indent:-1.5in'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>                                    </span>“The
technological singularity hypothesis is that accelerating progress in
technologies will cause a runaway effect wherein artificial intelligence will
exceed human intellectual capacity and control, thus radically changing or even
ending civilization in an event called the singularity.”<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2 style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p> </o:p></span></h2>

<h2 style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:2'>                        </span><span
class=GramE>“<a
href="http://www-rohan.sdsu.edu/faculty/vinge/misc/singularity.html">The Coming
Technological Singularity: How to Survive in the Post-Human Era</a>” (c)
1993 by <span class=SpellE>Vernor</span> <span class=SpellE>Vinge</span>.</span><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2 style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:3'>                                    </span>(Verbatim
copying/translation and distribution of this entire article <span class=GramE>is</span>
permitted in any medium, provided this notice is preserved.)<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>    </span><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2 style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:1.5in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-indent:-1.5in'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:2'>                                                </span>“Abstract:<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>     </span>Within thirty years,
we will have the technological means to create superhuman intelligence. Shortly
after, the human era will be ended.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> 
</span>Is such progress avoidable? If not to be avoided, can events be guided
so that we may survive?<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>These
questions are investigated. Some possible answers (and some further dangers)
are presented.”<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2 style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:1.5in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-indent:-1.5in'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span style='mso-tab-count:2'>                                                </span>“....
Just so I'm not guilty of a relative-time ambiguity, let me more specific: I'll
be surprised if this event occurs before 2005 or after 2030....”<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2 style='margin:0in;margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p> </o:p></span></h2>

style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>You get to make up your own mind.<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>;-)<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<h2><a name="_Project:_1"></a><span style='font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";
color:red'>Project:</span><span class=MsoHyperlink><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:windowtext;font-weight:normal;
text-decoration:none;text-underline:none'><o:p></o:p></span></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span class=GramE><b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;
background:yellow;mso-highlight:yellow'>Connect-K Game.</span></b></span><b><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast'><span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> 
</span>This project corresponds to Game Search (Chapter 5 in your book). Your
job is to write an AI agent that can beat you at Connect-K, i.e., to write the
adversarial search (game search) controller for a video game world. Shells are
available in C++ and Java.</span></b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast'><o:p> </o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast'>The tournament shell
will allow you to run different versions of your AI against each other, or
against your fellow students’ AIs, to explore which “great
ideas” make things better or worse. Bright and clever students might
implement a Local Search method (perhaps using genetic algorithms?) to explore
different improvements to their AI automatically, while they sleep?<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast'><o:p> </o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast'>I expect to be able to
run a tournament within which your AI controllers will compete against each
other for Bonus Points. Everyone’s AI will be entered into the tournament
automatically; the bonus points are simply free, based on how many games your
AI wins against other AIs. The top 10% winners will get 10% added to their
project grade as a bonus; the second 10% will get 9%; the third 10% will get
8%; and so on.<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast'><o:p> </o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:.5in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l2 level1 lfo2'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Wingdings;mso-fareast-font-family:Wingdings;mso-bidi-font-family:
Wingdings'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>v<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'> 
</span></span></span><![endif]><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Effective
immediately, the project grading structure is changed as follows:<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:.5in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>* <span
class=SpellE>AI_Poor</span>, <span class=SpellE>AI_Average</span>, and <span
class=SpellE>AI_Good</span> also will be entered into the Final Tournament
(these AIs are available in the "student coding resources" part of
the Project section of the class website).<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:.5in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>* You
will lose 20% of your Project grade if your AI does not beat or tie <span
class=SpellE>AI_Poor</span> at least once in the Final Tournament.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:.5in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>* You
will lose 10% of your Project grade if your AI does not beat or tie <span
class=SpellE>AI_Average</span> at least once in the Final Tournament (total loss
of 30% if your AI loses to both <span class=SpellE>AI_Poor</span> and <span
class=SpellE>AI_Average</span>).<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:.5in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>* You
will GAIN 10% BONUS added to your Project grade if your AI beats or ties <span
class=SpellE>AI_Good</span> at least once in the Final Tournament.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:.5in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>* As
previously stated, the top 10% in the Final Tournament will receive 10% BONUS,
the second 10% will receive 9% BONUS, <span class=GramE>the</span> third 10%
will receive 8% BONUS, and so on.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:0in;margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:.5in;
margin-bottom:.0001pt'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>* <span
style='background:yellow;mso-highlight:yellow'>So, if you are clever and your
AI is smart, you can receive up to a total of 20% BONUS.</span><span
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'><o:p></o:p></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast'><o:p> </o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast'>(1) A Java shell.<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast'>(2) A C++ shell.<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast'>(3) A tournament shell,
which will let you play different versions of your AI against themselves to
refine your evaluation function.<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast'>(4) Three example AIs,
which you or your AI can play against: a good AI, an average AI, and a poor AI.<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast'>(5) The “<span
class=SpellE>DummyAI</span>” source code, which your cleverness and
ingenuity will make smart.<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast'>(6) Several readme*.txt
files: readme.txt, readme-cPlusPlus.txt, <span class=GramE>readme</span>-tournament.txt.<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast'>(7) <span class=SpellE>ConnectK</span>
hints, caveats, and heuristics.<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast'>(8) A changelog.txt.<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast'><o:p> </o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;background:yellow;
mso-highlight:yellow'>Please note:</span></b><b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast'>
We'll run the tournament on SGE or a lab machine. The C++ target platform
should be x86. You should write your code to run on any x86 <span class=GramE>machine</span>.
The OS is CentOS 6. We most likely will need to compile your code with CentOS 6
(RHEL 6) x86_64. Machines in the openlab.ics.uci.edu (family-guy.ics.uci.edu)
are CentOS 6.<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast'><o:p> </o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;background:yellow;
mso-highlight:yellow'>Please note:</span></b><b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast'>
Connect-K, like most board games of its type, has a built-in advantage to the
first player (e.g., chess grandmasters try to win if they are white and play
first; they try to draw if they are black and play second). A
“fairer” game would have the first player make one move; then the
second player make two moves; then the first player make two moves; and so on,
alternately making two moves each, to neutralize the first-move advantage. The
point of this exercise is for you to write a “smart” AI, not to win
board games; nevertheless, be sure to run your AI both as first and second
player, then average the results.<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast'><o:p> </o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast;background:yellow;
mso-highlight:yellow'>Please note:</span></b><b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast'>
The shells may change as the quarter progresses.<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>If so, we will try to keep the interface
the same, so that all you need do is change the surrounding shell.<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast'><o:p> </o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:
"Times New Roman";mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast'>Several of my various
CS-171 projects were written by former CS-171 students who became interested in
AI and signed up for CS-199 in order to pursue their interest and write
interesting AI project shells.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> 
</span>Please let me know if this is of interest to you (CS-171 grade of A- or
better required).</span></b></p>

style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p> </o:p></span></b></p>

<h2><a name="_Study_Guides_---"></a><span style='font-size:12.0pt;font-family:
"Arial","sans-serif";color:red'>Study Guides --- Previous CS-171 Quizzes,
Mid-term, and Final exams:</span><span class=MsoHyperlink><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";color:windowtext;
font-weight:normal;text-decoration:none;text-underline:none'><o:p></o:p></span></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Previous
CS-171 Quizzes, Mid-term exams, and Final exams are available here as study
guides.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p> </o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>As an
incentive to study this material, at least one question from a previous Quiz or
Exam will appear on every new Quiz or Exam. In particular, questions that many
students missed are likely to appear again. If you missed a question, please
study it carefully and learn from your mistake --- so that if it appears again,
you will understand it perfectly. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p> </o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Also, a
student has recommended ‘quizlet.com’ as a good online study
resource. While I cannot vouch for it, apparently it contains several good
study aids for your textbook.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p> </o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>A kind and
helpful student has brought it to my attention that the PDF reader on a Mac
(iPad) sometimes has difficulty correctly reading the previous CS-171 tests.
For example, in problems #3a and #3b on Quiz #2 from SQ’2004, the
erroneous “Y” on the key was corrected by an overlay in the PDF
file of a red X through the Y, and next to it a red N. However, this overlay is
invisible on a Mac (iPad), leading to incorrect understanding of the right
answer. Sometimes, the Mac PDF software appears to be incompatible with the
Windows PDF software. If you are using a Mac to read the previous CS-171 test
PDF files and something looks wrong, please look at it again from Windows. If
it still looks wrong, please bring it to my attention.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p> </o:p></span></p>

<h2><a name="_Academic_Honesty:"></a><span style='font-size:12.0pt;font-family:
"Arial","sans-serif";color:red'>Academic Honesty: </span><span
class=MsoHyperlink><span style='color:windowtext;text-decoration:none;
text-underline:none'><o:p></o:p></span></span></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Academic dishonesty is unacceptable
and will not be tolerated at the University of California, Irvine. It is the
responsibility of each student to be familiar with, and without exception to
adhere to, UCI's current academic honesty policies.<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p> </o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><u><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>This class has a “zero
tolerance” policy toward academic dishonesty.</span></u></b><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>
Any student who engages in cheating, forgery, dishonest conduct, plagiarism, or
collusion in dishonest activities, will receive an academic evaluation of ``F''
for the entire course, with a letter of explanation to the student's permanent
file. The <a href="http://www.ics.uci.edu/grad/sao/index.php">ICS Student
Affairs Office</a> will be involved at every step of the process.<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p> </o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><u><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Please take the time</span></u></b><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>
to read the current <a
href="http://senate.uci.edu/uci-academic-senate-manual-2/part-iii-appendices-of-the-irvine-division/appendix-viii-uci-academic-senate-policy-on-academic-honesty/">UCI
Senate Academic Honesty Policy (UC Irvine Academic Senate Manual, Appendix
VIII)</a>, also reproduced in the <a
href="http://catalogue.uci.edu/appendix/#academichonestytext">Appendix of the
UCI Catalogue</a>, which states, among other things:<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.5in'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>“....
Academic dishonesty is unacceptable and will not be tolerated at the University
of California, Irvine. Cheating, forgery, dishonest conduct, plagiarism, and
collusion in dishonest activities erode the University’s educational,
research, and social roles. They devalue the learning experience and its
legitimacy not only for the perpetrators but for the entire
community....”<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p> </o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><u><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Please also review</span></u></b><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>
the <a href="https://www.ics.uci.edu/ugrad/policies/Academic_Integrity.php">ICS
Undergraduate Student Policies: Academic Integrity</a>, which states, among
other things:<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.5in'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>“Academically
Honest Conduct:<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>To be academically <span
class=SpellE>integrous</span> means holding to values such as honesty, fairness,
respect, and accountability in your scholastic pursuits. Students are expected
to follow the rules and guidelines established by instructors for assignments
and <span class=GramE>exams,</span> and to accept responsibility for his or her
own work....”<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p> </o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><u><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Please also review</span></u></b><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>
<a href="http://honesty.uci.edu/">Academic misconduct at UC Irvine</a>. A
summary of that information is: <o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpFirst style='text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo6'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol;mso-fareast-font-family:Symbol;mso-bidi-font-family:
Symbol'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>        
</span></span></span><![endif]><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Any student cited for Academic
Misconduct will have the report kept on file for 5 years.<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo6'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol;mso-fareast-font-family:Symbol;mso-bidi-font-family:
Symbol'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>        
</span></span></span><![endif]><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>During this time, a second incident
report would likely trigger suspension or dismissal from UCI.<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle style='text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo6'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol;mso-fareast-font-family:Symbol;mso-bidi-font-family:
Symbol'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>        
</span></span></span><![endif]><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>A single incident on file usually also
results in the student being ineligible for honors at graduation.<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpLast style='text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo6'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol;mso-fareast-font-family:Symbol;mso-bidi-font-family:
Symbol'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>        
</span></span></span><![endif]><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Many graduate and professional
programs request this information and it may affect admission.<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'><o:p> </o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><u><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Please also review</span></u></b><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>
the <a
href="http://www.dos.uci.edu/conduct/students/code-of-student-conduct-grounds-for-discipline.php">UCI
Code of Student Conduct: Grounds for Discipline</a>, which lists, among other
offenses:<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpFirst style='text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo8'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol;mso-fareast-font-family:Symbol;mso-bidi-font-family:
Symbol'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>        
</span></span></span><![endif]><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>102.01: All forms of academic
misconduct including but not limited to cheating, fabrication, plagiarism, or
facilitating academic dishonesty. Refer to <a
href="http://senate.uci.edu/uci-academic-senate-manual-2/part-iii-appendices-of-the-irvine-division/appendix-viii-uci-academic-senate-policy-on-academic-honesty/">Academic
Senate Policy on Academic Honesty</a>.<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoListParagraphCxSpLast style='text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l1 level1 lfo8'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol;mso-fareast-font-family:Symbol;mso-bidi-font-family:
Symbol'><span style='mso-list:Ignore'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>        
</span></span></span><![endif]><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>102.02: Other forms of dishonesty
including but not limited to fabricating information, furnishing false
information, or reporting a false emergency to the University.<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><u><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";
color:red'>The policies in all of these documents will be adhered to
*scrupulously*. No exceptions.</span></u></b><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'> <o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>We aggressively watch and monitor all
Quizzes and Exams. All Quizzes and Exams include your row#, seat#, ID#, and
ID#-to-right, so that we can reconstruct *exactly* the seating pattern in the
exam room. We know next to whom you were seated, and so we easily can check for
suspicious patterns of answers.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>All
source code and all written reports are subject to automatic text-based
plagiarism detection.</span></b><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><u><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast'><o:p></o:p></span></u></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><u><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif";color:red'><o:p><span style='text-decoration:
 none'> </span></o:p></span></u></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>My responsibility is to the honest
students who succeed based on their own merit and hard work. <u>If you are
cheating, then we are *aggressively* out to catch you. Penalties are severe.</u>
The worst part of my job is to have to catch and penalize a cheating student.
Please do not do this to me or to you. <o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-family:"Arial","sans-serif"'>Dr.
Lathrop strives very hard to create a level playing field for all students.</span></b><span
class=MsoHyperlink><span style='color:windowtext;text-decoration:none;
text-underline:none'><o:p></o:p></span></span></p>
